flares.note: This flare originates from beyond the east limb as seen from SDO AIA imagery and is likely occulted.

cmes.note: Narrow, bright CME seen to the south-southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1 and to the southeast in STEREO A COR2A. The likely source is a thin streamer of plasma lifting from near AR 4334 (S17E43) with noticeable southern deflection seen best in SDO AIA 304 and SDO AIA 171 around 2026-01-05T07:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using all available spacecraft out to 12 solar radii which suggests strong southern deflection.

cmes.note: Faint CME seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO, STEREO A COR2A and GOES CCOR-1 possibly associated with a two-part eruption in AR 4334 (S17E43) seen best in SDO AIA 171 around 2026-01-05T08:20Z; while most of the plasma material is directed southward, a portion of the plasma lags behind and is directed to the southeast. May instead be associated with a destabilizing magnetic loop with bright post eruptive arcades high above the AR 4334 (S17E43), but the ejecta does not leave the GOES and SDO EUV field of views until after 09:00Z, suggesting that any such CME associated with the later eruption in AR 4334 is seen after 09:00Z in coronagraph imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A SECCHI COR2A, and GOES CCOR-1 out to about 12 solar radii.

cmes.note: CME seen to the southeast in GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2 but not in SOHO LASCO due to a data gap; the CME is probably associated with destabilizing magnetic loop with bright post eruptive arcades near AR 4334 (S17E43) seen best in SDO AIA 171 around 2026-01-05T08:20Z seen through 2026-01-05T09:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Low confidence leading edge measurement using triangulation between GOES and STEREO A to determine the originating source longitude.

cmes.note: Wide CME first seen to the East in SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-06T02:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This CME is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2026-01-05T17:23Z to 2026-01-06T04:23Z. The source of this event is a C2.2 class flare and associated eruption from Active Region 14334 (S15E33) which began at approx. 2026-01-06T00:15Z. This flare is visible in SDO AIA 131, along with dimming seen in SDO AIA 193 and 211. Field line opening can be seen in SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: Very faint CME first seen to the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-06T07:36Z. This event is too faint to be clearly seen in SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2. The likely source of this event is some general field line movement near Active Region 14334 (S15E30) seen in SDO AIA 171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2.

cmes.note: Faint CME first seen to the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-06T12:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1. This CME is not clearly seen in STEREO A COR2. The source of this event is likely field line movement seen along the NE limb in SDO AIA 171 beginning at approx. 2026-01-06T11:42Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement due to source near the limb and lack of STEREO A for triangulation.

cmes.note: Narrow CME first seen to the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-06T14:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. This CME is obscured by the pylon in GOES CCOR-1. The source of this event is a minor filament eruption seen from near AR 14334 (S15E27) beginning at approx. 2026-01-06T13:31Z as seen in SDO AIA and GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: CME visible to the NE in STEREO A COR2, SOHO LASCO C2/C3, and GOES CCOR-1. The source is likely a C4.0 flare starting at 2026-01-06T15:43Z from Active Region 14334 (S13E25) as seen in SDO AIA 131. An eruption with dimming and post-eruptive arcades is best seen in SDO AIA 193. This CME likely exhibits deflection within the field of view. A smaller eruption is seen from Active Region 14336 (approximately S09E57) starting around 2026-01-06T15:07Z, but the larger eruption is believed to be the most likely source candidate.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2 imagery in SWPC_CAT as well as the potential source location. Only one frame of STEREO A COR2 imagery was available for this measurement, so the fit is approximate.

cmes.note: CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. The CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2026-01-06T18:23Z. The source is likely far-sided, with no clear source on the disk seen in EUV imagery. Field line movement may be seen beyond the SE limb in SDO AIA 171 in ISWA starting around 2026-01-06T21:06Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 running difference imagery in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the ESE in STEREO A COR2 starting around 2026-01-07T04:23Z. The exact start time is somewhat unclear due to imagery quality. This CME is also seen in to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. The leading edge of the CME is extremely faint and difficult to see in white light imagery. The source of this CME is likely associated with one of a series of eruptions from AR 14334. The eruption beginning around 2026-01-07T03:00Z associated with a C2.9 flare from AR 14334 (S15E18) that peaked at 2026-01-07T03:54Z is the most likely source candidate. The eruptive behavior, including some filamentary structure, and flare can be see across SDO wavelengths but are best seen in SDO AIA 131 and SDO AIA 304. There appears to be some deflection possibly due to the southern extension of coronal hole W of AR 14334 that was centered approximately around S18E05 at the time of the eruption.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit among SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1 as well as the visible on-disk source location.

cmes.note: CME visible to the SE in STEREO A COR2 and the SSE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. The CME may be partially obscured by the pylon in GOES CCOR-1. The likely source is an eruption with dimming seen south of AR 14334, around S30E25, starting around 2026-01-07T03:52Z as best seen in SDO AIA 193. The eruption is also seen from the point of view of STEREO A 195, closer to the southeast limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location and the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the E in STEREO A COR2 starting at 2026-01-07T06:53Z. This CME is only seen in STEREO A COR2. The source is most likely an eruption from AR 14334 (S15E16) associated with a C7.4 flare that peaked at 2026-01-07T06:12Z. The flare is best seen in SDO AIA 131, and the associated eruption is best seen in SDO AIA 193 and SDO AIA 304. There appears to be some deflection possibly due to the southern extension of coronal hole W of AR 14334 that was centered approximately around S18E03 at the time of the eruption.

cmeAnalyses.note: This measurement is somewhat subjective because this CME is only visible in STEREO A COR2. The longitude in the measurement is based on the source location on the Earth-facing disk.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the SE in STEREO A COR2 starting at 2026-01-07T10:38Z. This CME is also seen to the SSE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. It is partially obscured by the pylon in GOES CCOR-1. The source of this CME is most likely continuous eruptive activity from AR 14334 (S15E14) that persists for several hours starting as early as 2026-01-07T09:00Z. The ejecta that is most likely associated with this CME is best seen leaving the solar disk in SDO AIA 193 around 2026-01-07T12:07Z. There is some deflection likely due to the proximity to the southern extension of coronal hole W of AR 14334 that was centered approximately around S18E00 at the time of the eruption.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit among SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1 as well as visible source on the Earth-facing disk.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the north/northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best f it between SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is an eruption observed over/near the northwest limb starting around 2026-01-08T02:20Z as seen in SDO AIA 131/171/193/304 and GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 imagery. An opening of field lines can also be observed over the northwest limb at this time in SDO AIA 131/171/193 and GOES SUVI 171/195/284 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event is more narrow as observed by STEREO A COR2 imagery, while a wider feature is observed in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. The source is an eruption and C4.4 flare from Active Region 14334 (S18E05) starting around 2026-01-08T05:30Z as seen in SDO AIA 131/171/193/304, GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 and STEREO A EUVI 195/304 imagery. Ejecta can be observed deflecting southeast of the eruption site, possibly due to a nearby coronal hole west of AR 14334.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement following the wider feature seen in SOHO LASCO imagery. The measured parameters were obtained between the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible as a halo in GOES CCOR-1 imagery and a partial halo directed to the west in STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event is not seen in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery in real-time due to a planned gap between downlink periods starting at 2026-01-08T09:48Z. The source of this event is far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event. However, it is possible this event is associated with former Active Region 14321, which is would have been located roughly around S02E169 at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Bulk measurement tracking the inner, brighter feature based on the best fit between GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.
SHOCK measurement following the fainter, outer feature. The measured parameters were obtained from the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the E/SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. It is not clearly seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery. There is no clear source for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: This CME measurement includes at least three separate fronts visible in SOHO LASCO C2 frames that morph into what appears to be one single CME within the SOHO LASCO C3 field of view. Therefore it was measured as one CME.

cmes.note: This CME is only visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery to the west. There is no clear source for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky fit using STEREO A COR2 (longitude of 141 based on STEREO A COR2's POS at start time of CME).

cmes.note: Faint CME seen (mostly in running difference imagery) to the E in SOHO LASCO and GOES CCOR-1, covered by the data gap in STEREO A. The source is likely an eruption N of AR 14336 (S10E33), seen as dark moving ejecta in SDO AIA 304 starting at 2026-01-08T14:48Z and centered initially ~(N03E30). There could be eastward deflection of this CME because of a small coronal hole just west of its source.

cmeAnalyses.note: One-coronagraph analysis (SOHO LASCO) based on the location of the source eruption.

cmes.note: Faint CME to the E in SOHO LASCO and GOES CCOR-1, closely following CME: 2026-01-08T15:48Z. There is a real-time data gap in STEREO A COR2. No source for it has been found in EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: The CME is not seen in STEREO A COR2 coronagraph because of a daily data gap and no source has been found for it in EUV imagery. Only plane-of-sky analysis is possible.

cmes.note: Bright partial halo CME to the S and SE in SOHO LASCO and GOES CCOR-1 coronagraphs, fnot seen in STEREO A COR2 due to the daily data gap. Its source is a massive, very complex filament eruption S and E of Active Region 14334 (S19E03), potentially involving two erupting filaments (one directly south of this active region and another more to the east. This eruption starts after ~2026-01-08T16Z to the SE of disk center and is associated with the long-duration C5.6 flare in this active region peaking at 2026-01-08T17:30Z. It is seen in SDO AIA 304/193 as bright, extensive post-eruptive arcades, a large-area dimming, faint EUV wave and erupting filaments seen in 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis of the fainter leading shock front with one coronagraph method (SOHO LASCO and GOES CCOR-1) based on the shape of the front; this analysis fits the location of the source - flare and eruption near AR 14334.
Approximate, one-coronagraph (SOHO LASCO) analysis of the southern lobe of this two-lobed event based on the location of the source. The source is a long filament, so analysis is very approximate.
Approximate, one-coronagraph (early SOHO imagery and GOES CCOR-1 imagery) analysis of this CME based on the location of the source location (south of AR 14334).

cmes.note: Partial halo CME seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO and GOES CCOR-1 at the same time as the more southern CME: 2026-01-08T17:12Z. Alternatively, these two events could be two lobes of the same CME. This event is fully obscured by the daily data gap in STEREO A. The source could be the more eastern part of the complex U-shaped filament eruption to the SE of Active Region 14334 (S19E03) (or potentially one of two erupting filaments). This complex eruption starts after ~2026-01-08T16Z to the SE of disk center. It is seen in SDO AIA 304/193 as bright, extensive post-eruptive arcades near the active region, a large-area dimming, and faint EUV wave. Erupting filaments are seen in SDO AIA 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate, one-coronagraph (SOHO LASCO) analysis of the eastern lobe of this complex eruption.

cmes.note: Very faint possible CME front visible only in difference imagery to the N/NW in SOHO LASCO C2. The source is believed to be a C3.4 class flare from AR 13443 (S14W04) with a very clear dimming structure and associated EUV wave heavily deflected to the N/NW as seen in SDO/AIA 193. This deflection may be due to coronal holes nearby.

cmeAnalyses.note: HIGHLY SPECULATIVE ANALYSIS. Very faint front measured to the N/NW starting with the potential source location and adjusting to fit the front. Deflection highly likely with this event based on dimming seen on solar disk.

cmes.note: CME observed to the SE in STEREO A COR2, also observed to the S in SOHO LASCO C3 following a data gap ending at 2026-01-09T04:22Z and in GOES CCOR-1 heavily obscured by the pylon. No distinct source for this CME is observed, but is likely outflow following large CME 2026-01-08T17:00Z from Active Region 14334 (S19E03) and a large dimming region to its south. SWPC_CAT triangulation corroborates this on-disk source.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C3.

cmes.note: CME observed to the SE in STEREO A COR2, also observed to the S in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 following a data gap ending for LASCO C2 at 2026-01-09T04:17Z and in GOES CCOR-1 heavily obscured by the pylon. No distinct source for this CME is observed, but is likely outflow following large CME 2026-01-08T17:00Z from Active Region 14334 (S19E03) and a large dimming region to its south. SWPC_CAT triangulation corroborates this on-disk source.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: This narrow CME is faintly visible to the west in STEREO A COR2 imagery. It is not seen in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. There is no clear source for this CME, but based on lack of visibility in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 it is likely a far-sided event from Earth's perspective.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky parameters based on best fit using STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT. The longitude for STEREO A's plane-of-sky is roughly 141 degrees at the start time of the CME.

cmes.note: CME observed to the SE in STEREO A COR2, also observed to the S in LASCO C3 following a data gap ending at 2026-01-09T12:30Z and in GOES CCOR-1 heavily obscured by the pylon. The source is likely outflow following large CME 2026-01-08T17:00Z from Active Region 14334 (S19E03) and a large dimming region to its south, with some extra dimming observed centered around S60E20 in SDO AIA 193 starting around 2026-01-09T06:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: STEREO A COR2 only measurement due to SOHO data gap and GOES CCOR-1 pylon obstruction of the CME, using the observed source centered around S60E20 as a basis. As such the latitude and longitude could easily vary +-5 degrees either direction, but high confidence in being out of the ecliptic.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the south in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and southeast in STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event is not seen in GOES CCOR-1 as it is blocked by the pylon. The source may be related to faint dimming centered near S50E20 starting around 2026-01-09T14:30Z seen in SDO AIA 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: A very faint narrow jet-like CME seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 difference imagery and possibly seen very faintly in one or two timestamps of STEREO A COR2 after the data gap (but very faintly). Too faint to discern the front in GOES CCOR-1 and C3. Source could be a minor movement of field line on SE limb seen in SDO AIA 171 seen ~2026-01-10T01:50Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very speculative analysis since the only possible (and extremely minor) source seems to be on/close/behind the SE limb in SDO AIA 171 but (a very uncertain) fit with two coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2 and one or two rather questionable timestamps of STEREO A COR2) produces a fit of ~70 deg of longitude.

cmes.note: Very slow, streamer blowout CME first seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting around 2026-01-10T16:12Z. This CME is also seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1. There is no definitive source for this CME on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit among SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2. SOHO LASCO C2 was not used as the CME moves more slowly in early frames.

cmes.note: Thin jet-like CME observed to the S in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, obscured by the pylon in GOES CCOR-1 and unseen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 2026-01-10T14:53Z. The source is a complex eruption associated with a C2.1 flare (S16W04) from AR 14339 peaking at 2026-01-10T19:42Z observed in SDO AIA 131, observed as what is likely two bulk fronts as CME: 2026-01-10T20:36Z and CME: 2026-01-10T20:48Z. Following the flare, filament ejecta is observed in SDO AIA 304 traveling S/SW but appearing to mostly fall back onto the disk likely associated with this CME, and that is followed by dimming starting around 2026-01-10T19:57Z centered around S27W02 observed in SDO AIA 193 likely associated with CME: 2026-01-10T20:48Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Half width less than 10 degrees. Single spacecraft 3D analysis due to lack of COR2A imagery and CCOR-1 pylon obstruction, using the observed flare source S16W04 as a basis. However, observed deflection of the CME in SDO AIA imagery and the inability to triangulate with other coronagraphs makes this analysis speculative, and the latitude/longitude could easily range within +-10 degrees.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the S in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, obscured by the pylon in GOES CCOR-1 and unseen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 2026-01-10T14:53Z. The source is a complex eruption associated with a C2.1 flare (S16W04) from AR 14339 peaking at 2026-01-10T19:42Z observed in SDO AIA 131, observed as what is likely two bulk fronts as CME: 2026-01-10T20:36Z and CME: 2026-01-10T20:48Z. Following the flare, filament ejecta is observed in SDO AIA 304 traveling S/SW but appearing to mostly fall back onto the disk likely associated with CME: 2026-01-10T20:36Z, and that is followed by dimming starting around 2026-01-10T19:57Z centered around S27W02 observed in SDO AIA 193 likely associated with this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Single spacecraft 3D analysis due to lack of COR2A imagery and CCOR-1 pylon obstruction, using the observed dimming source S27W02 as a basis. However, observed deflection of the CME in SDO AIA imagery and the inability to triangulate with other coronagraphs makes this analysis speculative, and the latitude/longitude/half-width could easily range within +-5 degrees.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1, not in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 2026-01-10T14:53Z. The CME front appears to form within the LASCO C2 field-of-view rather than appear behind the occulting disk, as such the start time is this first visible frame. No distinct on-disk source is observed.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO LASCO C3 only plane-of-sky due to unobserved source and no STEREO A COR2 to triangulate.

cmes.note: Faint CME first seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting around 2026-01-11T01:25Z. This CME is also seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 but is not seen in STEREO A COR2. There is no obvious source for this CME on the Earth-facing disk, so it is most likely far-sided. The is some minor field line movement near/beyond the SE limb best seen in SDO AIA 193 starting as early as 2026-01-11T00:12Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement (Lon. -90) based on running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: Narrow, jet-like CME first seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2026-01-11T05:12Z. This CME is also seen to the NE in SOHO LASOC C3, GOES CCOR-1, and very faintly in STEREO A COR2. There is no definitive source for this CME on the Earth-facing disk, so the source is most likely far-sided. There is slow, broad field line movement, beyond the E limb for several hours prior to the start of this CME best seen in GOES SUVI 284, but it is most likely unrelated.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit among SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: CME visible to the east in GOES CCOR-1 and in running difference imagery in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 in real-time. Not visible in STEREO A COR2 in real-time due to a data gap. The potential source may be an eruption with dimming near S10E50 starting around 2026-01-11T16:12Z, best seen in SDO AIA 193. This CME is quickly overtaken in the field of view by CME with ID 2026-01-11T22:45:00-CME-001.

CME seen to the east in GOES CCOR-1 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source is an M3.3 flare as seen on the east limb across all wavelengths of SDO/AIA imagery starting at 2026-01-11T21:53Z. Rapidly opening field lines and post-eruptive arcades are also visible. The potential source for this flare and CME may be AR 14321, possibly located around S10E115, which rotated off of the Earth-facing disk on 2025-12-31, and may be a region of interest seen in NSO/GONG data.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on potential source location using GOES CCOR-1 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery in SWPC_CAT.
Shock measurement based on the potential source location, with adjustment to best fit the shock of the CME in GOES CCOR-1 and SOHO LASCO C3 imagery.
